title: If the Big Bang happened again exactly as it happened 13.8 billion years ago, would the outcome be exactly the same, or is there a fundamental randomness built in the universe that the formation of Earth as we know it would be unlikely? - Quora

response.answer_text: Question: If the Big Bang happened again exactly as it happened 13.8 billion years ago, would the outcome be exactly the same, or is there a fundamental randomness built into the universe that the formation of the Earth would be unlikely? There is a fundamental randomness built into the universe due to quantum mechanics.That randomness is not so very different than the randomness that already existed in classical mechanics. People pretend that it is very different, but it is not. Quantum mechanics simply prevents people from asking certain questions about nature at all.We have no way to calculate the way that the whole universe would behave in the first place. This is independent of whether the underlying laws are classical or quantum mechanical. No one can calculate the probability that you ask for.This doesn’t mean that the formation of the Earth would be “unlikely” due to this fundamental randomness. There are many possible ways for the Earth to have formed. Not exactly here perhaps, but somewhere, not exactly the Earth we know, but something close to it.There is randomness, yes, but quantum mechanics makes very strong and very definite non-random predictions, if you can define the problem well enough. It is not so vastly different than classical mechanics that way.

Predicting anything 0.3 billion years in the future, is just about impossible, especially when it’s subject to things as small as the movement of individual molecules. (Just look at Saturn’s rings. Or our total inability to predict the next asteroid that will come close to, or hit, Earth.) And, as Gould said, rewind evolution and let it start again, and we wouldn’t end up with the same species we have now (and for the same reasons - if one creature didn’t have one reproductive cell hit by one cosmic ray, some new feature might never have occurred). So yes, there’s enough randomness that the universe may have formed with different enough constants that life would be impossible. that matter itself would be impossible, anything. Likely? Maybe or maybe not, we can’t tell. But possible? Certainly.

Q: If the Big Bang happened again exactly as it happened 13.8 billion years ago, would the outcome be exactly the same, or is there a fundamental randomness built in the universe that the formation of Earth as we know it would be unlikely? A: Quantum processes which dominated the early universe are statistical in nature. Thus rewind the universe we’d end up with a similar but different universe. The universe at the large scale would still look pretty much the same. It is just the fine details that would differ. There would be no “Earth” as we know it but there would probably be other Earth like planets, as there surely are now already. You and I wouldn’t be here. Our solar system and even galaxy cluster wouldn’t be the same. But all the physical laws might be exactly the same. Thus resulting in a universe that looks roughly the same as it does now at the largest scales.

That’s one of the lowest probability “ifs” I’ve ever heard of, but I can pretend it could happen. Based on the physics we know today the initial probabilities of all particle and field interactions would be exactly what they were in the beginning of our universe, but the results of the interactions would not be determined. It would then be even more unlikely that the evolution of this other universe would proceed as ours did than that it could start exactly as ours did.

Nobody knows, but the way to bet is that the same initial conditions would not necessarily produce an identical outcome, due to the fundamental quantum randomness. The deterministic classical laws of Nature are understood as what happens on average over a very large number of quantum level statistical interactions.

We don’t really know, but I think the overwhelming majority of physicists today would say that, if you go back far enough, detail like the Earth is extremely unlikely to be repeated. There appears to be, at the quantum level, some underlying true randomness in the universe, and therefore the detailed working out would be different every time, even if the large scale was statistically very similar.

If you go by Futurama then it's exactly the same only slightly higher. But in all seriousness, no one has a clue. We don't know if we are in the result of the first big bang or if there are many. Humbling to think instead of 14billion years, the universes could have existed for billions of billions of years. Your guess is as good as anyone's.
